title: 103_hr3464
content:
The "Comprehensive Arson Deterrence and Fire Containment Act of 1993" authorizes funds for the modernization of the Modular Airborne Fire Fighting System. The Forest Service will study ways to improve airborne fire fighting response time and report to Congress within a do year period. Additionally, the Act proposes increased criminal penalties for arsonists. The "Comprehensive Arson Deterrence and Fire Containment Act of 1993" proposes increased criminal penalties for malicious use of fire or explosives on federal property, including fines and imprisonment based on the extent of damage or risk to human life. The "Comprehensive Arson Deterrence and Fire Containment Act of 1993" proposes escalating penalties for arson or explosives offenses based on the extent of damage or risk to human life, including fines and imprisonment ranging from 5 to 40 years, and potentially the death penalty for cases involving fatalities. The "Comprehensive Arson Deterrence and Fire Containment Act of 1993" proposes escalating penalties for arson or explosives offenses based on the extent of damage or risk to human life, including fines and imprisonment ranging from 5 to 40 years, and potentially the death penalty for cases involving fatalities. Offenders could face fines or imprisonment up to 10 years, with harsher penalties if damage exceeds $1,000,000 or if a person's life is endangered. The penalties for offenses under the "Comprehensive Arson Deterrence and Fire Containment Act of 1993" are as follows: 
- Offender fined and imprisoned for 5-20 years if damage exceeds $1,000,000
- Offender fined and imprisoned for 8-30 years if life is endangered or damage exceeds $10,000,000
- Offender fined and imprisoned for 10-40 years if personal injury occurs or damage exceeds $25,000,000
- Offender faces fine, imprisonment greater than 25 years (or life), and potentially the death penalty if a person dies. The penalties for offenses under the "Comprehensive Arson Deterrence and Fire Containment Act of 1993" include fines, imprisonment for various durations based on the extent of damage or harm caused, and the possibility of the death penalty if a person dies as a result of the offense. Additionally, reckless conduct resulting in destruction of property or injury to others may lead to fines, imprisonment up to one year, or community service. The penalties for offenses under the "Comprehensive Arson Deterrence and Fire Containment Act of 1993" include fines, imprisonment, and community service. Offenders may be sentenced to probation with a minimum of 100 to 2000 hours of community service, or imprisonment for up to one month or one year, depending on the severity of the offense. Juveniles may also be required to spend time in a residential institution for juvenile delinquents. The court may sentence a person convicted under this section to probation with a minimum of 100 to 1000 hours of community service or imprisonment for up to one month. Juveniles adjudicated as delinquents may spend time in a residential institution and perform community service. The Forest Service will study federal legal impediments to clearing fire hazards and report to Congress. The Secretary of Defense will report on using military cargo for firefighting. Insuring firefighting water supply and backup power will also be addressed. The Forest Service, in consultation with fire experts, will study building roads and backup power for ensuring water supply in national forests to enhance firefighting. Results will be reported to Congress within a year. Additionally, the Secretary of Agriculture will reduce below-cost loans for the Farmers Home Administration by 5% for fiscal years 1994-1998.
